awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Cholinergic and sleep regulation of human learning and memory
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to learn and remember facts, experiences, and skills is critical for a wide range of human activities.  Although how experience is encoded into memory, how such memory is then consolidated and later retrived have been extensively studied by psychologists and neuroscientists, a critical context in which memory processing taking place has been understudied.  That is the natural rise and fall of the neurochemicals that are known to influence a wide range of brain functions through the sleep and wake cycles.  Here Dr. Sara Mednick of the University of California, Riverside (UCR) and Dr. Michael Silver of the University of California, Berkeley (UCB) and their colleagues will investigate how acetylcholine (Ach), a major neuromodulator known to play a critical role in learning and memory, might differentially affect neural processing at the stages of encoding, consolidation, and retrieval.  Rivastigmine a drug for treating Alzheimer's Disease, will be given to human subjects to increase Ach just before training (encoding), just after training (consolidation in the waking state), just before bedtime (sleep-dependent consolidation), and just before testing (retrieval). Brain electrical activity will be monitored using high-density electroencephalography (EEG) to characterize how different cortical regions are affected by both natural variations in ACH associated with sleep-wake cycles and by pharmacological treatment. Together, these experiments will provide the critical empirical data to test theories of learning and memory that take into consideration of dynamic changes in neuromodulation

Acetylcholine has been associated with Alzheimer's disease, a neurodegenerative disease that affects over 5 million Americans. Better understanding of ACh's role in mechanisms of memory will help treat patients with the disease and also develop tools for enhancing healthy memory as well. A better understanding of neurochemical mechanisms of learning and memory will also help improve educational practice and applied training regimes, and investigations of the role of sleep in this project will help emphasize the importance of sleep in a society that has record low levels of sleep and impaired functioning due to poor sleep habits. Dr. Mednick and Dr. Silver will develop teaching modules and courses on the roles of sleep and acetylcholine and learning and memory as well as a course on sleep methods that will help train students to conduct research in this area. Finally, Dr. Mednick will present public lectures on the health benefits of sleep at local Hispanic-serving public hospitals and will work with the UCR Health Center to promote napping and healthy sleep habits in college students through Nap-Ins and other university-wide events.

por.por_cntn:
The laboratories of Sara Mednick (University of California, Riverside) and Michael Silver (University of California, Berkeley) conducted collaborative research to investigate how the brain changes when people acquire a new visual skill and memorize information. We also administered drugs to study participants to learn about the neurotransmitters in the brain that contribute to learning and changes in the brain during learning.

 

We used a technique called high-density electroencephalography (hdEEG) to measure the electrical activity in different parts of the brain without the need for surgery or other invasive procedures. This technique involves placing many electrodes on the scalp of the participant and recording the activity of neurons in the brain underneath each electrode. We trained subjects to make judgments about the orientations of lines presented on a computer screen. With practice, subjects substantially improved their ability to perform this visual task, and this improvement in visual perception was accompanied by changes in a number of neural markers, as assessed with EEG. Specifically, neural responses associated with processing of sensory information, allocation of visual attention, and cognitive processes were all altered by the training procedure. For some of these responses, the size of the effects of training in a given person were related to the amount of improvement in task performance. These results give us insight into the changes that take place in the brain when people acquire a new skill.

 

In another study, subjects learned to associate pairs of words during training and were later asked to recall which words had been previously shown to them in pairs during the training period. As in the study described above, we documented changes in brain responses that were associated with the learning (in this case, memorizing the pairs of words). We also recorded brain activity while the subjects slept the night after training. Here, we again found reliable markers of brain activity that were related to the learning process. This research adds to a large and increasing knowledge base about the importance of sleep in facilitating the process of long-term storage of memories and experiences.

 

In addition to our studies of brain changes during learning, we also characterized some basic properties of learning in our experiments. In one study, we found a novel and surprising result: retention of a learned visual skill was better four weeks after training than it was two weeks after training. This is highly counterintuitive, because for many types of memory, the ability to recall decays with the passing of time. In contrast, we have discovered an “anti-forgetting” effect, in which the memory is strengthened over time, perhaps due to additional periods of sleep.

 

Finally, we examined the effects of the drugs rivastigmine and donepezil on skill learning and memorization of word pairs. These drugs are both cholinesterase inhibitors, a class of drugs that is the most common medication-based treatment of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. Based on our previous work, we expected that these drugs would enhance learning. Surprisingly, we generally found that they did not have a beneficial effect on learning in our studies. These results provide important information about the conditions under which these drugs do and do not improve learning. This is useful not only for our understanding of Alzheimer’s disease but also for efforts to optimize learning and training procedures for rehabilitation from brain injury, for “brain games”, and in workplace and educational environments.
